It's been a while to play a proper detective game where your focus is mainly on you and the world around you while also doing your job as well. The lore is superb, you keep want to learn more about it and the characters are just straight out of the reality. Like there's no "right" or "wrong" way to do things or talk about. Since you're a human and others are, so not everything goes like a checklist in a linear way in most of the games we see.

Your set of skills is super important but it's not like if you miss one thing you'll be locked out of the game or something very crucial. And sometimes you can salvage the situation but sometimes it was already too late. The voice acting in this game is just god-tier, it's insane how much different characters they fit in this so small world. And the things you pay attention or do has its own effects in the future conversations or actions. It's really masterfully done and you need to improvise a lot if you want to get through from tough situations.

Writing is also on par with acting so the world they created is one of a kind and really portrays people's feelings towards the things happened in the past and nowadays. Probably Disco Elysium is the only game that captures the emotional and intellectual complexities of human beings perfectly. You can clearly see it throughout in the game. The most mesmerising thing about the game is your inner voices and feelings which is a great add-on and they do sure make the game much fun, like by tens of thousands.

You can't go blind like trusting everything they say but sometimes they do make sense even the least sane of your feelings so you have to pick carefully otherwise you might end up with very absurd situations which is fun. You really get a grasp of your character's mental struggles and how he copes against the world and the events that affected him so you can either redeem yourself and lead by example or just drag yourself into the lowest of lows with all around you.

It's a shame we never get a second one and what they did to the developers so yeah it's a sad reality. It's very ironic, game mocks of capitalism does the very thing he swore to destroy. If you're into this kind of games then you've played this already. So for new comers I don't think it's not that overwhelming unless you're playing on hardcore mode so you can save scum to try again or go with to the end see what happens. I did both depending on the situation, mostly went with the original outcome to be realistic as possible but of course bad rolls happen in the most unexpected times.

I enjoyed every second of it, and I wish it was much longer and never ended. Really one of a kind.

Amazing how sometimes completely trivial situations happen to trigger incredibly complicated and messed up sequences of events. That's a nice way to describe Disco Elysium. It doesn't try to come up with something extraordinary just to stumble upon a challenge of tying up all the loose ends. In a sense it's like a storm that's so sporadic and methodical at the same time. You have a direction but that's not the real point. The most outstanding parts are interwoven through: the city, the people, their motivations and relationships. Same kinda goes for the gameplay and roleplaying elements. Vertical dialogue box and basic skills developed into parts of Harry's psyche are such neat and organic details.

It's completely absurd yet so elegant. Often way out there but so relatable in the end. Disco reminds that you're not supposed to resolve everything life throws at you. It's a story about coming to terms with yourself and the world around. Some things you leave behind and move on. And some things always stay with you.

Disco Elysium is a pretty exceptional surrealist detective role playing game.
Your initial goal of solving a murder in the city of Revachol quickly spirals and branches out into an intricate web of really memorable quests and encounters all across the city.  

The world building and character work in this game are incredibly strong, having your skill system be structured as representing all the facets of your physiological profile and having those personality traits clash and interact with each other over the course of the game is pretty genius. Many potential fail-states can lead to really hilarious outcomes and the game does a great job of de-insentivizing just reloading and trying again. 

If you run Logic, Perception and Empathy as your main skills, you’ll be an eagle-eyed, hyper logical ‘relatively’ (focus on relatively) emotionally stable super detective. Whereas if you run completely different traits like Drama, Electrochemistry or Inland Empire, you’ll have a wildly different experience, like being a free-wheeling psychotropically-stimulated coked-out sociopathic maniac. 

Some of the funniest stuff I’ve ever heard in a video game are in Disco Elysium, there’s some savage, amazing responses to conversations you can have with people. There are also some legitimately excellent dramatic interactions you have as well, which do a great job of adding real depth to many of the characters you meet throughout the story.

Disco Elysium is a non-traditional RPG with stellar writing, interesting world-buidling and a keen sense for  all the major and minor philosophical and political implications of the human condition. The run-down, pitiful bleakness of it's world serves as a stark and effective contrast to the sheer delusional grandiosity of the MCs inner monologue. 

The way your character tries to make sense of the world by listening to the voices in his head is witty and cynical, sometimes touching, occasionally absurd - but steadfastly humanizing. The same goes for all NPCs sharing the world. You'll meet colorful people from all walks of life, with varying convictions, motives and flaws - but never devolving into mere caricatures. That's what makes it special.

Disco Elysium is also a massive heap of (brilliantly voice-acted) text that loves to elope on intrigueing but absolutely inconsequential tangents, so buckle up! You'll be rewarded with one of the most unique and memorable gaming experiences ever.

Disco Elysium is one of the most unique and brilliantly written RPGs I’ve ever played. Its world feels alive, its characters are unforgettable, and the freedom it gives you to shape your detective’s personality makes every playthrough feel personal. The writing is sharp, funny, and emotional all at once, and the game constantly rewards curiosity and creativity. An absolute must-play for anyone who loves storytelling in games.

Now I have only played 6hrs of this 'interactive novel' I'd call it, and I can't wait to see what else is in store. You're presented with this 'clean' slate of a character to build your own personality upon, or make one up entirely with the unique trait system. Want to be a walking encyclopedia, knowing facts about everything? Maybe someone who daydreams far too much to the point where you can talk to your own necktie? A scary fasination for chemical abuse? And the best part is that all these different 'traits' of you have their own voice, and chime in during dialogue when relevant.

I've never been a reader of books or anything, especially in this age of short-form content, but there is something about this game that keeps me engaged with every character I meet; they're incredibly well written, hard to forget, and the dialogue options never fail to entertain. You'll wander through the town and recall every conversation you had with these people. I also can't shake this feeling of having to 'impress' my detective partner, Kim, at any possible given opportunity as I feel that I am having to uphold this title of 'detective' even though we're definitely not qualified. Where is my gun and badge?

Today we’re talking about ZA/UM’s 2019 role playing game, Disco Elysium.

A dialogue heavy story told through skill checks dice rolls and a thirst for… Oblivion

Harry is an amnesiac cop sent to the mucky port city of Revachol, deep in the district of Martinaise. A melancholy world painted through an emotional collage of oil. A war-torn zone of control, caught between a political limbo and economic depression. 

You, Along with your ever-composed partner, Kim, are part of the Revachol Citizens Militia. Investigating the murder of the hanging man.

Uncover the secrets and history behind Revachol as decaying architecture expands beneath your feet into a world that’ll swallow you whole. Running into eccentric and unforgettable characters along the way, such as the philosophical Cuno.

-“What’s with that third person shit, Cuno is first person”-

The writing in this game is so deeply immersive, done in a way I could only hope for. Sometimes holding the mirror up to you, breaking the 4th wall in amusing and unsettling ways, reminding you who’s really in charge.

Get lost in the words as they brush the wrinkles on your brain. Every choice shaping your personality and defining who you are or may become. 

Fans of Baldurs Gate 3 or Return of the Obra Dinn should definitely give this game a try.

You’ll find yourself engrossed for days in this murder mystery RPG. By the time you’re done your chair will have a butt imprint, and the once rigid, harsh streets of Revachol will sit as a cozy memory in your head.
So if you give it a shot, let me know what you think.

This is one of the best games I have ever played. There is nothing like it. This is art. It can be kind of hard to get into though but just give it a fair try and it will sink its teeth into you. The story is the main reason to play this game, don't come for the gameplay, (which is not the focus anyway) come for the story, and I promise you will stay for the story. The story is depressing at first glance, but if you dig deeper, it is truly beautiful. It really makes you think about yourself, politics, economics, romance, and what it means to be human. I encountered concepts and perspectives that had never crossed my mind before [laying, and I am confident in saying that I am better for it. 

	The characters in this game are truly amazing. They all feel like real people, with real stories that you get to uncover. They are very memorable and full of soul, partly due to the amazing voice acting. It is all top notch; the voice actors did a lovely job. Every single line is delivered with thought and care, enhancing the experience to greater heights. 

	The gameplay, which was never a draw for me, is still good. It is mostly talking to people, but most conversations are well written and interesting. It is fun and lets you experiment and do and say weird stuff, without punishing you for it, in fact, sometimes the game encourages you to say some outrageous things to make progress, which is all great. 

	A final thing I want to highlight is the visuals. They are lovely. Each of the characters' portraits are beautiful paintings that tell you everything you need to know about the character by looking at them. The world is mostly bleak, but with splashes of color that remind you it is still alive and there is still hope for positive change. 

The worst thing about this game, however, has nothing to do with the game, and everything to do with the publishers. They effectively stole this game from its creators, soooo... do with that what you will. (if you catch my drift) 

Overall, this is an experience unlike any other, and everyone should at least give it a fair try. It is one of the best stories ever written with amazing characters, writing, and art direction.

This game shook me because I've already learned the darker lessons and hard truths life ultimately teaches you. As a huge fan of Planescape: Torment and older story-driven CRPGs in general, I'd just like to say: this is not the spiritual successor that everyone promised me, and unless you walked away from Planescape: Torment thinking, "Golly, that sure was a lot of reading I had to do to finish that game," you might feel the same.

Disco Elysium feels as if it suffers from being grossly misclassified, as it's only just barely an RPG. Personally, I'd describe it as a visual novel... with skill checks. I'd also describe it as a [i]highly political[/i] visual novel, one which you normally wouldn't so much as give a second glance unless you had a keen interest in political discourse, which is far more niche than the overwhelmingly positive reviews and the discourse surrounding it might suggest.

That's not to say there's nothing else on offer in Disco Elysium, but [i]boy,[/i] you are going to be reading a [i]lot[/i] about Revachol, its history, its rulers, its neighboring countries, the various governmental bodies of the world, the local political factions and their beliefs, and you're going to hear absolutely [i]everyone's[/i] opinions on these topics, again and again [i]and again.[/i] It's the lifeblood of the narrative and it's baked into every facet of the setting, it's completely unavoidable, and I found this to be [i]incredibly[/i] disheartening.

Sadly, there's also a compelling exploration of the player character and the existential crisis he's wrestling with, expressed beautifully through his internal monologue (dialogue?), but it's more of a B plot, unfolding quietly in the background over the course of the game. Moreover, like our own never-ending processes of self-examination, it feels as if it has very little bearing on the direction of the narrative, only really affecting the ways in which you interact with others. Like all the other roleplaying tidbits at play here, it's just a bit of personalized flavor for you to enjoy, and one that might occasionally season your dialogue without meaningfully changing the outcome, nothing more and nothing less.

All of this is to say: Disco Elysium is a wonderfully written piece of fiction, but it's not as widely accessible as the hype surrounding it might imply, nor is it a particularly compelling RPG. Ultimately, [i]it's also just really not for me.[/i] I wrote this review to work those feelings out and to let anyone else who bounces off Disco Elysium know: [i]you're not alone.[/i]

Full Review:
This isn't a game for people who've been through certain types of trauma. Namely, trauma having to do with your self esteem and value. First of all, you do NOT get to customize a character. One is given to you and he's already a psychological mess. If you have deep wells of empathy this game will trigger you in a way that is more harmful than good. The overall message is for people who haven't yet developed the skills or life experience to understand the illusion of choice is not freedom. It's a game with a very dark, nihilistic message. While Nihilism can be enlightening and even freeing for some people, this game doesn't really allow you to explore those aspects of it. It tends to repeatedly highlight only the worse parts of humanity in a context absent of hope or empathy. Why the devs would include an entire segment of dialogue that analyzes and breaks down racism in support of it, is a confusing and concerning choice. There are better ways of exposing how toxic racism is without glorifying at the same time. The game is definitely thought provoking but it does it in a very abusive manner that could be harmful to people who struggle with CPTSD, AuDHD and healthy emotional regulation. 
This game shook me because I've already learned the darker lessons and hard truths life ultimately teaches you. I didn't need a rerun of trauma and I think the lessons could be learned without it, but I understand why some people feel it's necessary. It might be a great game, but it's not for everybody and that's why I can't recommend it.
